Jynxzi - Twitch BALL x PIT on Steam Could Open Graph Just Be a CSS Media Type? | Scott Jehl, Web Designer/Developer https://webawesome.com Podcast Awesome Quiet UI A Beautiful Site Eleventy is a simpler static site generator Don‚Äôt use custom CSS mouse cursors ‚Äì Eric Bailey Home | Rach Smith's digital garden The Two Button Problem ‚Äì Frontend Masters Blog Sponsors tldraw Have you ever wanted to build an app that works kinda like Miro or Figma, that has a zoomable infinite canvas, that‚Äôs multiplayer, and really good, but you also want to build it in React with normal React components on the canvas?
Good news! tldraw is the world‚Äôs first, best, and only SDK for building infinite canvas apps in React.
tldraw takes care of all the canvas complexities ‚Äî things like the camera, selection logic, and undo redo ‚Äî so that you can focus on building the features that matter to your users. It‚Äôs easy to use with plenty of examples and starter kits, including a kit where you can use AI to create things on the canvas.
Get started for free at tldraw.dev/shoptalk, or run npm create tldraw to spin up a starter kit.

item.title: Episode 487: My manager ignores me during 1:1's and I am required to work in an empty office
item.description: In this episode, Dave and Jamison answer these questions: ‚ÄúMy manager insists on a weekly 1:1 with me, but he rarely pays attention. He‚Äôs often on his laptop, texting, checking email ‚Äî basically anything but listening. I‚Äôve tried sending agendas, rescheduling, reducing frequency, waiting until he‚Äôs less busy ‚Äî nothing helps. I‚Äôve even started sitting in silence until he notices I‚Äôve stopped talking, but that only works for a minute. This has caused real problems. For example, he almost had me cancel a million-dollar project because he misheard me say ‚ÄúJava‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúJavaScript.‚Äù When he finally realized I was right, he said, ‚ÄúEvery time I heard Java I automatically tuned out.‚Äù How do I handle a 1:1 with a manager who won‚Äôt pay attention, without risking my work or my relationship with him?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked for a big retailer for 10 years now and I used to really enjoy it. I liked my team a lot, problems we worked on, technologies we used. Unfortunately the last few yours brought a few rounds of layoffs and my old team doesn‚Äôt exist anymore and the new team is pretty much awful. They‚Äôre all on the East Coast, while I‚Äôm on the West Coast. I‚Äôm required to work EST hours but also to commute to the office 5 days a week and sit there alone and talk to my team on zoom. I‚Äôm a staff software engineer and I haven‚Äôt been programming much for the past year. Most of my time is spent in calls, I start every day with the same 3 calls. I live 50 miles from the office and I take a company shuttle that leaves at 7am. I‚Äôm required to join the calls from my phone. I leave for work at 6:30am, I‚Äôm back at home at 6:30pm. A few times a week I need to do deployment at 10pm. I tried speaking to my manager and to my director. They don‚Äôt care. My every attempt to improve our processes is met with opposition. My manager is afraid of changes. I can‚Äôt believe this is where I am but I‚Äôm too tired to prepare for job hunting. I can‚Äôt afford to quit. I don‚Äôt know how to get myself on track and dust off my programming and interviewing skills. I‚Äôm praying they‚Äôll lay me off so that I can use the severance to do all those things. But this isn‚Äôt really a plan, it‚Äôs wishful thinking, and I‚Äôm afraid that my career options are getting worse by the minute. Do you have any advice on how to get myself out of this hell hole?‚Äù

item.title: 122: Snapchat Drops Valdi‚ÄîA New Challenger to React Native?
item.description:
In a surprise move, Snapchat open sources its cross-platform UI Valdi. Valdi lets devs write UI components in TypeScript then compiles them to native views on iOS, Android, and macOS, offers instant hot reload without recompiling, and integrates well into already existing native apps.¬† GitHub Universe 2025 wrapped up just a few weeks ago, and it had a bunch of new AI agent updates to share. Think: a single source to manage agents across GitHub, Mobile, CLI, and VS Code, custom agents with tailored prompts and tools, new Copilot integrations and agentic code review, and Plan Mode.¬† TanStack DB released v0.5 and Query-Driven Sync. With Query-Driven Sync, a component‚Äôs query is the API call and DB handles the fetching, caching, and updating, and provides different sync modes for different use cases.¬† Chapter Markers:

item.title: First look at Prisma ORM v7 with Will Madden
item.description: Jack Herrington talks with Will Madden about how Prisma ORM is evolving in v7, including the transition away from Rust toward TypeScript, less magic, and a new Prisma config file for more predictable good DX. item.title: Why Astro Is Winning Developers Over with Sagi Carmel - JSJ 697
item.description:
In this episode, I sit down with developer and speaker Sagi Carmel to dive deep into Astro, why it‚Äôs gaining so much traction, and how it compares to frameworks like Next.js, Nuxt, Remix, and SvelteKit. We explore what makes Astro uniquely powerful ‚Äî from its server-first approach and island architecture to its simplicity, speed, and ability to integrate with any front-end framework you want. Sagi also walks me through real-world use cases, including how he built Israel‚Äôs official Census website with Astro, why scoped CSS and server components simplify the development experience, and how tools like HTMX and view transitions make web UX buttery smooth. If you‚Äôve been curious about Astro, this conversation is a terrific deep dive into both its fundamentals and its advanced capabilities. üîó Links & Resources Astro Documentation: https://astro.build HTMX: https://htmx.org Looker (Google Cloud): https://cloud.google.com/looker BigQuery: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery Sagi Carmel on YouTube: @SagiCarmel Sagi Carmel on LinkedIn: Search ‚ÄúSagi Carmel‚Äù

item.title: 956: Should I Keep Using WordPress?
item.description:
In this potluck episode, Wes and Scott answer your questions about paid vs. free SSL, the state of frontend jobs, headless WordPress trade-offs, organizing TypeScript types, and more!
